name: Priti Patel
Basic Info: Priti Patel, Conservative MP for Witham
Property Analysis: Priti Patel voted against the Renters' Rights Bill, which would have improved tenant rights.
max_hospitality_description: Two tickets with hospitality in the Legends Suite at Silverstone for the British Grand Prix (£1,650 each)
DonorCategories: the Premier League and its clubs, the Embassy of Bahrain
Hospitality Analysis:
Priti Patel has received a total of £7,370 in hospitality and gifts since the last election.
This means he!she ranks at #10 for most hospitality received.
The most expensive declaration was worth £3,300, described as 'Two tickets with hospitality in the Legends Suite at Silverstone for the British Grand Prix (£1,650 each)' from Silverstone Circuits Ltd.
He!She has received 3 gifts valued at over £500.
He!She has declared gifts or hospitality from the Premier League and its clubs and the Embassy of Bahrain.
The Premier League and its clubs have been lobbying to water down regulations designed to ensure greater sharing of revenues throughout the sport.
The UK government has been accused of collusion with the oppressive practices of the government of Bahrain by continuing to sell them arms despite well-documented human rights abuses.
Other Analysis:
Priti Patel has claimed a total of £6,462 in expenses since the last election.
His!Her expense total all comes from office costs.

name: Paul Waugh
Basic Info: Paul Waugh, Labour MP for Rochdale
Property Analysis:
He!She has claimed for his!her utility bills to be paid by the taxpayer. Even so, in 2024 he!she voted to abolish universal winter fuel payments for 10 million pensioners. 2.5 million of these pensioners had 'incomes below levels needed for a dignified life', according to the Centre for Ageing Better.
He!She has claimed £127 for utility bills for his!her personal accommodation.
Other Analysis:
Paul Waugh has claimed a total of £16,585 in expenses since the last election.
His!Her expense total comes from £9,838 in accommodation costs, £5,788 in office costs and £960 in staffing costs.
He!She voted in support of the UC and PIP bill, which will cut the universal credit allowance for many disabled people by £2,080 per year.

Housing and Accommodation:

He has claimed £17,529 in accommodation expenses since the last election.
He has claimed for his utility bills to be paid by the taxpayer. Even so, in 2024 he voted to abolish universal winter fuel payments for 10 million pensioners. 2.5 million of these pensioners had 'incomes below levels needed for a dignified life', according to the Centre for Ageing Better.
He has claimed £549 for utility bills for his personal accommodation.

Other Information:

Stephen Morgan has claimed a total of £39,005 in expenses since the last election.
This places him in the top 10% of MPs for expenses claimed.
His expense total comes from £17,529 in accommodation costs, £19,136 in office costs and £2,340 in staffing costs.
He voted in support of the UC and PIP bill, which will cut the universal credit allowance for many disabled people by £2,080 per year.

Hospitality and Gifts:

Stephen Morgan has received a total of £1,780 in hospitality and gifts since the last election.
The most expensive declaration was worth £1,500, described as 'Three nights' accommodation during the Labour Party Conference' from HM Government of Gibraltar.

You can get more detail from IPSA or Parliament about his expenses and financial interests.

Racing and gambling companies have been lobbying to reduce protections for gambling addicts and reduce the taxes collected on gambling.

Outside Earnings:

This means he!she ranks at #7 for most outside earnings.

name: Chris Murray
Basic Info: Chris Murray, Labour MP for Edinburgh East and Musselburgh
Property Analysis: He!She has claimed £12,900 in accommodation expenses since the last election.
Other Analysis:
Chris Murray has claimed a total of £41,704 in expenses since the last election.
This places him!her in the top 10% of MPs for expenses claimed.
His!Her expense total comes from £12,900 in accommodation costs, £27,004 in office costs and £1,800 in staffing costs.
In 2024, he!she voted to abolish universal winter fuel payments for 10 million pensioners. 2.5 million of these pensioners had 'incomes below levels needed for a dignified life', according to the Centre for Ageing Better.
He!She voted in support of the UC and PIP bill, which will cut the universal credit allowance for many disabled people by £2,080 per year.
